With Test Mentor (which among other things discovers and runs JUnit tests)
we use the JPDA http://java.sun.com/products/jpda/ to dynamically monitor
method entry events during test execution. It then reports on which methods
were hit and which ones weren't, using reflection to gather a list of the
methods that were expected to have been hit.

The other interesting thing we've been doing lately with this method entry
data is to walk the stack frames on method entry notification to find the
calling methods, and then build an object interaction diagram from that.
Besides displaying the interactions (useful for debugging) we're also using
them to generate more tests for lower level collaborating objects.

> Hi,
>
> I'm trying to put together a test coverage metrics reporting
> tool, and want
> to know if anyone has tried doing this yet. (I'm sure someone
> has.)   What I
> what to do is generate a report that shows some stats on how many classes
> have test cases and how many methods in the class under test have
> corresponding test methods.  I have tried it a few different ways:
>
> 1. Just scanning through the source folder, picking up the java files and
> then checking if a ?Test.java file exists in a corresponding unit test
> folder.
>
> This approach works well if I only cared about the file coverage,
> but I now
> want info on the method coverage.  Enter method 2.
>
> 2. Use a tool that will parse through the java source and tell me all the
> methods. I used javadoc for this, but the problem with it is that
> I can only
> sort through one source structure at a time, and javadoc is not so nice to
> call programmatically (it shuts down your app after it runs once).
>
> If anyone has suggestions on a better was to get info on the methods in a
> class, and other information like is the class an interface, I
> would love to
> hear it.  Or better yet, if anyone has seen or built a tool
> similar to what
> I'm doing I would also love to hear about it.
>
> Thanks,
>
> John
